column8: Reign of Emperor Xiaoming of Han

The Old Catalog calls this Emperor Xiao Ming Sūtra of Forty-Two Sections. Master Dao'an’s Catalog omits this scripture.

The previous item is one part in a total of one fascicle. Emperor Xiaoming of Han had a dream of a golden man. The emissary Zhang Qian, accompanied by the Yu Lin [Palace Guards] commanded by General Qin Jing, to the Western Regions. When they arrived at Tokara met the monk Kasyapa-Matanga. He returned with them to Luoyang where he translated this scripture. It was stored in Room 40 of the Orchid Terrace. Today the scripture is in general circulation.

[From Introduction T 2145, 55.0005b16] The ancient scriptures, as they are now [arranged], do not begin with [the Sūtra of] Forty-Two Sections, as supposed by the envoy Zhang Qian. It is difficult to confirm when these chapters were translated.

column41: There is a preface to this sūtra included in fascicle 6 of the Chu San Zang Ji Ji, which is similar to the preface in the Taishō. Funayama (2013, 22) states that this actually appeared in the early fifth century or later. Heng-ching (2017, 27-28) states that it is a compilation of ideas from many sūtras and that Mahayana and Daoist elements in the text may have been added at a later time. Nattier (2008, 35-36) notes that there are obvious problems with the historical accuracy of the preface. In particular, the figure Zhang Qian 張騫 mentioned in the preface as being dispatched by Emperor Xiaoming of Later Han was a well-known figure who actually lived in the secondary century BCE.

column18: Lokakṣema produced the Sūtra on the Prajñāpāramitā Practice of the Way in ten fascicles and Gu Pin Yi Ri Shuo Bore in one fascicle. Zhu Foshuo produced the Dao Xing Jing in one fascicle, which is an abridged version of the Prajñāpāramitā Sūtra. Zhu Shixing produced the Fang Guang Jing in twenty fascicles, also known as the Jiu Xiao Pin. Dharmarakṣa later retranslated the Xiaopin Jing in seven fascicles. Wei Shidu compiled an abridged version of the Large Sūtra on the Prajñāpāramitā Practice of the Way in two fascicles.   Dharmapriya produced the Mahāprajñāpāramitā Sūtra in five fascicles, which is also known as the Chang'an Chapters. Kumārajīva produced the new Large Prajñāpāramitā Sūtra (Da Pin) in twenty-four fascicles and the Xiao Pin in seven fascicles.

Lokakṣema produced a foreign version of the Parinirvāṇa Sūtra in one fascicle. Zhi Qian produced the Mahāparinirvāṇa Sūtra in two fascicles. Dharmarakṣa produced the Vaipulya Nirvāṇa Sūtra in two fascicles. Dharmakṣema produced the Mahāparinirvāṇa Sūtra in thirty-six fascicles. Shi Faxian produced Mahāparinirvāṇa Sūtra in six fascicles and the Vaipulya Nirvāṇa Sūtra in two fascicles. Shi Zhimeng produced the Nirvāṇa Sūtra in twenty fascicles. Guṇabhadra produced the Nirvāṇa Sūtra in one fascicle.

The Old Catalog has the Saddharmapuṇḍarīka Sūtra, why this title is different from the Lotus Sūtra is not clear and who produced it is missing. Dharmarakṣa produced the Lotus Sūtra in ten fascicles. Kumārajīva produced a new version of the Lotus Sūtra in seven fascicles.

Lokaṣema produced the Śūraṅgama in two fascicles. Zhi Qian also produced the Śūraṅgama in two fascicles. Baiyan also produced the Śūraṅgama in two fascicles. Dharmarakṣa the Yong Fu Ding [Śūraṃgama Samādhi] in two fascicles, which is also a version of the Śūraṅgama. Zhu Jilan also produced the Śūraṅgama in two fascicles. Kumārajīva produced a new version of the Śūraṅgama in two fascicles. The Old Catalog has  as Shu version of the Śūraṅgama in two fascicles but it is not clear who produced that.

Zhi Qian produced the Vimalakīrti in two fascicles. Dharmarakṣa produced the Vimalakīrti Sūtra in two fascicles and also produced the Shan Weimojie Jing in one fascicle. Zhu Shulan produced the Vimalakīrti in two fascicles. Kumārajīva produced a new version of the Vimalakīrti in three fascicles.

Zhi Qian produced the Amitābha Sūtra in two fascicles. Dharmarakṣa produced the Infinite Life Sūtra in two fascicles, also known as Wuliang Qingjing Pingdeng Jue. Kumārajīva produced the Infinite Life Sūtra in one fascicle. Shi Baoyun produced the Infinite Life Sūtra in two fascicles. Guṇabhadra produced the Infinite Life Sūtra in one fascicle.

Dharmarakṣa produced Sūtra on Three Hundred Similes in twenty-five fascicles but the subjects of the similes are not known for this title. Shi Faju produced the Dharmapada in six fascicles. Dharmarakṣa produced Akṣayamati in four fascicles. Zhu Fajuan produced  Akṣayamati in ten fascicles. Dharmakṣema later compiled the Akṣayamati in four fascicles.
Dharmakṣema produced the Bodhisattvabhūmi in eight fascicles. Tripiṭaka Master Guṇavarman produced the Bodhisattva Precepts in ten fascicles.

Dharma [Zhu Fanian] produced the Ten Part Prātimokṣa in one fascicle. Kumārajīva produced the Ten Part Prātimokṣa in one fascicle. Buddhayaśas produced the Dharmaguptaka Prātimokṣa in one fascicle. Shi Faxian produced the Seng Zhi Biqiu Jie Ben in one fascicle. Buddhajīva produced the Mahiśāsaka Five Part Vinaya Precept Manual for Monks in one fascicle.

Dharmarakṣa produced the Prātimokṣa for Bhikṣuṇī in one fascicle, now lost. Shi Sengchun produced the Bhikṣuṇī Ordination Vows in one fascicle. Shi Faying produced the Ten Part Prātimokṣa for Bhikṣuṇī in one fascicle. Mili transmitted the Bhikṣuṇī Ordination Vows in one fascicle, which was in the list of doubtful scriptures, now lost.

An Shigao produced the Scripture on the Five Dharmas of the Abhidharma and the Scripture on the Seven Dharmas in two fascicles, now lost. The Seven Dharmas and the Ninety-Eight Dharmas of the Abhidharma are now lost. Saṅghadeva produced the Abhidharma Vibhāṣa in forteen fascicles and the Abhidharmahṛdaya in sixteen fascicles. Saṅghavarman produced the Abhidharmamahāvibhāṣa in fourteen fascicles and the Abhidharmahṛdaya in four fascicles. The Indian Vibhāṣa produced the Śāriputrā Abhidharma in twenty-two fascicles. Buddhavarman produced the Abhidharmamahāvibhāṣa in sixty fascicles. Faxian produced the Saṃyuktābhidharmahṛdaya in thirteen fascicles. Īśvara produced the Saṃyuktābhidharmahṛdaya in thirteen fascicles. Saṃghavarman produced the Saṃyuktābhidharmahṛdaya in fourteen fascicles. It is not known who produced Katyayana’s Abhidharmahṛdaya in twenty fascicles and it has been entered in to the list of anonymously translated texts.

column5: Sūtra on the Wonderful Sound of the Lion’s Roar
column8: the fourth year of the Tianjian era [502-519]
column18:
In the fourth year of the Tianjian era [502-519], produced over a period of sixteen years (relying on the Zhang family). 

With regard to the sūtra mentioned previously, Jiang Mi, a scholar at the Imperial Academy in the late Qi dynasty, had an illegitimate daughter who became a nun. When she was a young child, she would sometimes close her eyes and sit in quiet meditation. During these times, she would recite this sūtra, claiming that it was from heaven or given to her by spirits. Her speech was fluent, as if from prior knowledge. She would instruct others to write it down, but then suddenly stop. After a period of ten days or a month, she would resume as before. The people of the capital, both religious and lay, widely spread rumors of her unusual abilities. The emperor at the time summoned her for an audience and asked for an explanation. She responded in a straightforward manner, not unlike a regular person, yet she was a devout believer in the true Dharma and had undertaken some religious practices. Her parents wanted to marry her off, but she adamantly refused. She later became a nun, taking the name Sengfa, and lived at the Qingyuan Temple. Since I am in the process of compiling and reviewing Buddhist texts and other unusual accounts, I have heard about this matter. I sought to examine her writings, but her family kept them secret and would not show them to me. I only managed to obtain the three-fascicle Sūtra on the Wonderful Sound of the Lion’s Roar, which I included in my collection of doubtful sutras. This nun died in the third month of the Tianjian era. There are some who, being curious, have obtained the written records of what she produced, both before and after this period.

The item above was produced in the ninth year of the Tianjian era [502-519] of the Liang dynasty, a nun from Yingzhou named Miaoguang claimed to have attained great spiritual wisdom, despite having only been ordained for seven years. Many nuns and laypeople declared her a saint. The Monastic Director of Yingzhou planned to expel her. Miaoguang secretly traveled to the capital and took residence at Puhong Temple. There, she created this scripture. She also copied the text onto a screen, draped it in red silk, and adorned it with incense and flowers. People from all four monastic groups gathered to make offerings, and the temple was filled with smoke from the incense. When her actions became widely known, an imperial decree ordered an investigation. The investigation revealed that she had plagiarized various other sūtra and had inserted her own ideas. It was also discovered that she had hired a scholar named Lu Yan to refine the language of the text. According to official court documents, Miaoguang’s cunning fraudulence warranted decapitation, and Lu Yan, as an accomplice, was to be exiled for ten years. On the 21st day of the fourth month of that same year, Emperor Wu of Liang commanded Monastic Director Huichao to summon twenty prominent and virtuous monks from the capital, including myself Sengyou and Tanzhun, to assemble at Jiankang to investigate Miaoguang's case. Huichao complied with the imperial order and, along with Tanzhun, Sengyou, and eighteen other monks including Facong, Huiling, Huiji, Zhizang, Sengmin, and Fayun, questioned Miaoguang at the county office. Miaoguang confessed to her crimes, and the details matched the court documents. The monks decided, based on monastic law, to expel and punish her.
The emperor spared her from the death penalty but, fearing that she might cause further deception elsewhere, ordered her to be imprisoned for life at the Eastern Prison. The authorities seized over twenty copies of the sutra and the screen, and they were all burned at the county office. However, some scattered copies still existed, so this record was made to prevent them from misleading future generations.
(Note: Saporuotuo was Miaoguang’s father’s name, his younger brother’s name was Jingangdeti, and her disciple’s name was Shizi.)

The two items above are collections from recent times. The dates and names of the authors are unknown. They bring together many sūtras and groups them by category. Once a title is established, a text like the 'Fa Yuan' is considered a separate scripture. Therefore, its name is annotated to show later scholars. Although the number of volumes is large, they are still just a collection of previously recorded sūtras. Thus, they are not included in the main section.
